import { Meta, Story, Preview } from '@storybook/addon-docs/blocks';
import { scaleBand, scaleLinear } from '@visx/scale';
import { letterFrequency } from '@visx/mock-data';
import ChartFrame from '../chart-frame';
import Bars from './';

<Meta title="Components/Bars" component={Bars} />

# Bars geometry

This is provided data and then draws bars.

Used in bar charts, obviously.

<Preview>
  <Story name="Basic">
    <svg width="300" height="400">
      <Bars
        width={300}
        height={400}
        xScale={scaleLinear({
          domain: [0, Math.max(...letterFrequency.map((d) => d['frequency']))],
        })}
        yScale={scaleBand({
          domain: letterFrequency.map((d) => d['letter']),
          padding: 0.1,
        })}
        automaticallySetRange={true}
      />
    </svg>
  </Story>
</Preview>

Here it is with a ChartFrame

<Preview>
  <Story name="With chartframe (responsive)">
    <ChartFrame title="Bars!" subtitle="BARRRRRS">
      <Bars
        yScale={scaleBand({
          domain: letterFrequency.map((d) => d['letter']),
          padding: 0.1,
        })}
        xScale={scaleLinear({
          domain: [0, Math.max(...letterFrequency.map((d) => d['frequency']))],
        })}
        automaticallySetRange={true}
      />
    </ChartFrame>
  </Story>
</Preview>

## <a id="Magnitude">Magnitude legend</a>

Uses circles sized by volme to denote minimunm and maximum values in a range of numeric data and other significant values in between. Most commonly used on bubble plots and uses the squareScale to define its structure.
